title: Patriots players got a surprise blue-collared gift from Mike Vrabel
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Patriots coach Mike Vrabel gifted blue collared shirts to the team, inspired by a similar gesture at the Browns.
The Patriots are preparing for a divisional game against the Jets after a seven-game win streak this season.
Coach Vrabel emphasizes leadership and consistency as key factors in the team's current success.

title: ‘Ride and Walk for Your Life’ pedals toward safer streets, will push for reform
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: 'Ride and Walk for Your Life Boston' events include a memorial bike ride, a walk, and a rally at the State House.
The initiative honors road traffic victims and urges Massachusetts legislators to pass laws improving road safety and truck regulations.
Advocacy groups seek to reduce traffic violence and promote safety measures, highlighting the impact of preventable fatalities.

title: Tips for getting stubborn bird droppings off of an SUV
author: John Paul
bullets: Warm water and dish detergent combined with a microfiber cloth can help remove stubborn bird droppings from a Jeep.
A handheld steamer, such as one from WORX products, is effective in removing hardened bird droppings on vehicles.
Professional car detailing is recommended if home remedies do not successfully remove bird droppings from vehicle surfaces.

title: Patriots have a new secret weapon on offense in 335-pound defensive tackle
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots use 335-pound Khyiris Tonga as a fullback, enhancing their offensive strategy with his blocking skills.
Tonga, traditionally a defensive tackle, has contributed to both offensive and defensive plays for the Patriots this season.
Coach Mike Vrabel values Tonga's versatility, highlighting his impact in three phases: offense, defense, and special teams.

title: What Joe Thornton said about the Bruins during his Hall of Fame induction speech
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Joe Thornton spent the first eight years of his NHL career with the Boston Bruins, scoring 454 points in 532 games.
During his Hall of Fame induction, Thornton thanked the Bruins and Boston, highlighting mentorship from Bruins alumni like Johnny Bucyk.
Thornton praised Wayne Cashman and noted maintaining a weekly friendship with him, emphasizing his appreciation for Boston's support.

title: Several key Patriots players still limited in latest injury report
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Kayshon Boutte and Rhamondre Stevenson among key players limited in Patriots' latest injury report.
Tight end Austin Hooper and defensive lineman Joshua Farmer did not participate in Tuesday's practice.
Several players, including Christian Barmore and Marcus Jones, fully participated despite recent injuries.

title: Man, ‘significant’ number of birds and snakes killed in Methuen house fire, department says
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: A Methuen house fire at 38 Atkinson St. killed a man and a significant number of birds and snakes.
The fire, reported around 2:20 a.m., resulted in catastrophic home damage despite four hours of firefighting efforts.
The Methuen Fire Department and State Police are investigating the fire's cause; three people escaped, but one man died.

title: What readers say Boston Mayor Michelle Wu should prioritize in her next term
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Mayor Michelle Wu's top priorities according to readers are housing affordability and public safety for her next term.
In a Boston.com poll, housing affordability and public safety were the most cited issues, capturing 49% of responses.
Readers highlight the need for policy changes in zoning, rent assistance, and enhanced public safety measures.

title: Pay transparency is now law in Massachusetts. What does it mean for you?
author: Pattie Hunt Sinacole
bullets: Massachusetts' new pay transparency law requires employers with 25+ employees to disclose pay ranges in job postings.
The law covers roles compensated by commissions, tips, or hourly rates and applies to remote workers reporting to Massachusetts firms.
Employers violating the law may face penalties, but they have a two-day grace period to correct violations.

title: Salem woman who ran ‘creepy creations’ shop to plead guilty in Harvard morgue scandal
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Katrina Maclean to plead guilty for selling stolen human remains from her Peabody store, sourced from Harvard morgue.
Maclean allegedly purchased remains from Cedric Lodge, former Harvard morgue manager, and stored them at Kat’s Creepy Creations.
Her plea deal includes a potential 12-month imprisonment, $250,000 fine, and right to appeal a prior dismissal motion denial.
